lessonOverview.title: Unit 7 - Lesson 2
structures: A: What do you do in art class?
A: What does he/she do in maths class?

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six class activities (paint pictures, solve maths problems, do experiments, sing songs, read maps, play sports) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Act out class activities (e.g. pretend to sing, solve maths problems). Students guess: “You’re doing music!” then point to SB image.
stretchStrategies: Class Fashion Show – Students work in groups. One models while the others describe: “She’s wearing a dress and trainers.” Rotate roles. Adds fun, repetition, and authentic use of target Q&A structures.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about school activities using “What do you do in ___ class?” / “What does he/she do in ___ class?” and respond with “I...” / “He/She...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) In pairs, show a subject flashcard. Partner asks: “What do you do in ___ class?” Student replies using target language.
stretchStrategies: Class Fashion Show – Students work in groups. One models while the others describe: “She’s wearing a dress and trainers.” Rotate roles. Adds fun, repetition, and authentic use of target Q&A structures.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What do you do in ___?” / “What does he/she do in ___?” / “I ___.” / “He/She ___.” to talk about class activities.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Display sentence strips: “What does he do in ___?” / “He paints pictures.” Mix them up—students reorder and practise aloud.
stretchStrategies: Class Fashion Show – Students work in groups. One models while the others describe: “She’s wearing a dress and trainers.” Rotate roles. Adds fun, repetition, and authentic use of target Q&A structures.

items: A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
